name: CONSUMER BEHAVIOR

values.comments:
MKTG211 is concerned with how and why people behave as consumers. Its goals are to: (1) provide conceptual understanding of consumer behavior, (2) provide experience in the application of buyer behavior concepts to marketing management decisions and social policy decision-making; and (3) to develop analytical capability in using behavioral research.

Most students agreed that this was a “fantastic course” that provides “real world experience to the student and the learning process which is felt throughout the project.” Students loved that they got to “engage in real world experience” although one student stressed “a lot of guest lecturers and so I feel I have become more familiar with specific companies than actual marketing tactics.” Many students found that the topics were interesting and the lab days were the “most useful part of the class.” Students liked that this course “uses a real-life Windows project” due to a Windows Phone/Microsoft partnership” which was “extremely valuable.”

	The majority of students loved Professor Reed, deeming him as “one of the most engaging Professors” they had ever met. Students liked that classes were “not a lecture but more of a lecture/discussion” where Professor Reed was “great at keeping interest during the class.” Students though he was “engaging, energetic and exciting.” Many students liked that there were “corporate guest speakers discussing topics that are highly relevant to recently learned material.” However, some students found that Professor Reed was “not great at responding to emails” and was “hard to reach outside of class.” One student also said that he “sometimes communicated different things on the deliberables. It wasn’t always clear what exactly we needed to turn in, when things were due, where documents were placed, etc.”
	
Many students were frustrated by the lack of exams or tests. One student stated “the entire grade is placed upon one assignment at the end. It is a little unclear what the expectations are.” Other students commented that they were required to “purchase a coursepack of slides that were 75% complete (that we had to fill in)”, and that students were required to spend money on the final project. However, students thought the final project was “a lot of fun, especially because we were helping a real company”. Students liked the goal of this project, which was “to come up with a segment and target the segment with certain advertising strategies”. Students stressed that there was a “lack of required coursework” although a lot of “work outside of class”. One student also complained that participation was evaluated through the Canvas site, and that they did not want to “have to worry about posting on the Canvas site for participation points”. The prerequisite for this course is MKTG 101, and is open to all SEAS and Wharton students.
